choices.answer: Where something happens.
The moral to the story.
What the story is about.
Which characters are in the story.

questions.question: True or False: A theme is something you can learn about human life.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: What is an example of a theme?

choices.answer: Little Red should have been more careful in the forest.
Elsa should not have been so careless with her powers.
Be careful what you wish for.
Bella knew what she wanted to be when it came time to it.

questions.question: True or False: A theme is a hidden message in a piece of a text.

choices.answer: True
False
Something you find out in one sentence.
Something you summarize.
Something you learn by making inferences.
Something you learn by looking for clues from the text.

questions.question: What does it mean if something is universal ?

choices.answer: It means that not everybody knows what it will mean.
It means that people will be who they are whatever happens.
It means you can travel through space and time.
It means that it can be applied to everyone on this Earth.

questions.question: True or False: Theme is not the most important element in a story or written work.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: True or False: The theme is bigger than just ONE character.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: What is an example of a theme?

choices.answer: Simba was too scared to face his truth.
People should not run away from their problems.
Maurice was a crazy man raving in the tavern.
Do not trust someone who is only interested in their self.
It is the theme.
It is the setting.
It is the topic.
It is the climax.

questions.question: Which of the following makes "love" a theme?

choices.answer: Love can help give you strength for what you need.
The story is just about love.
Simba and Nala found out they love each other.
LeShawn wanted to be loved, but no one did.

questions.question: Are books the model of what the real world and what it may be like?

choices.answer: Yes
No

questions.question: True or False: There is no wrong answer, if you can support it.

choices.answer: True
False

questions.question: Your theme should have at least __ supporting details.
What is one way you could compare and contrast your themes with a friend?

choices.answer: You tell them they are wrong.
You tell them how good the theme your friend wrote is.
You argue based on evidence found in the book.
You do not say anything because you know you are right.
